issue.title: Do more request parameter parsing ourselves
issue.body:
Rack is looking at some minor changes to how they parse query strings, but we have learned hard-won lessons about changing even edge case behaviours.

Simultaneously, this narrow instance has highlighted a more general situation: prior to Rack 3, we always had the option to adopt our own parameter parsing strategy (e.g. if we wanted to invent some meaning for a structured parameter name of `foo[@]/bar` or something). As Rack 3 eliminated the obligation for the input body to be rewindable, only the first-to-read is guaranteed to be able to see the full set of parameters.

The Rack side of this has been alleviated via https://github.com/rack/rack/pull/2088 -- it's still true that only the first reader can parse the input, and ecosystem consistency requires that reader to be Rack... but it will now provide a more literal, less processed, view of the parameters it saw.

Here, we adopt that new raw parameter list (where available), and do the structured parsing for ourselves.

Interestingly, this allows us to be more direct in getting to a true Rails parameter set: indifferent hash access, nil munging, and string encoding controls can all be applied as we go, instead of through post-processing.

---

The intention is that there are no observable behaviour changes here: the only short-term effect will be to insulate us from future-Rack's https://github.com/rack/rack/pull/2098.

This PR _will_ result in new/different internal exception classes being raised for various invalid-parameter situations, but apart from changing spelling of some log messages, I'm not sure it's practical, let alone likely, for an application to be seeing/rescuing them: we already translate the Rack exceptions to `ActionController::BadRequest`, and here maintain that translation for the new ones.

body: If this is Rack 2 only, perhaps it can be a motivator for https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/50565?

Thanks for noticing and reporting this!

I picked up Rack 3's fix of https://github.com/rack/rack/issues/1732, which was not intentional... though the alternatives of allowing both characters for everyone, or conditioning our behaviour on the Rack version, both seem also-not-great.

ü§î

@matthewd would you consider a Rails config and/or deprecation for this? The consensus on that Rack issue was that this could be a big breaking change (confirmed!), so I think that would ease the upgrade path now that we are decoupling from Rack a bit more. If you're üëç on this, I can work on it.

Yeah, my current thought is that the best option might be to silently adopt the Rack 3 behaviour if Rack 3 (or more accurately, not-Rack-2) is present [so we don't regress/change behaviour for people already using Rack 3], but then when Rack 2, use a config setting:

Default to `"&;"`, `load_defaults` it to `"&"`, deprecation warning if the application doesn't set it (and is using Rack 2).

If the config is set, we should follow it regardless of Rack version.

That way: if someone is already on Rack 3 [or upgrades to Rack 3 at the same time as Rails 8.0], they have already [or will then] follow the Rack 3 upgrade path (silent switch-over, ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è)... but anyone who upgrades to Rails 8.0 while still on Rack 2 will keep the Rack 2 behaviour for now, while we can also proactively nudge them to be explicit about what they want.

(All the "middleware/proxies might disagree = danger zone" stuff applies as soon as Rails and Rack apply different opinions, as we would via this config, but I think informed danger is probably a more workable upgrade path than safe breakage.)

Hey folks, wanted to add another example of a regression that appeared after upgrading Rails to include parsing changes.

In our case the application started to parse queries with nested structure in a different (broken) way. However while preparing the reproduction script I realized that in our case the same failure happens when using rack `3` which I suppose means that the application is the one that needs to change here as it won't be compatible with rack 3. And the change in Rails just revealed this incompatibility earlier. 

So I'm mainly sharing for additional and to potentially think of a possibility to provide a better heads-up for applications that may experience the same.

On a side note, I'd like to learn if `[cart][apple]=1&[cart][banana]=2"` format was even officially supported or just happened to work. Because if it was intentionally supported it could mean much higher rate of applications relying on it and breaking in ambiguous ways when migrating to rack3 or next rails version.
**Update**:  https://github.com/rack/rack/issues/2128 this leads me to believe that it should be considered an application problem 

<details>
<summary>Reproduction script</summary>

  ```ruby
  require "bundler/inline"

  gemfile(true) do
    source "https://rubygems.org"

    # with parsing changes
    gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main", ref: "d64611bc5a71a749d10c4da295e80fe182b5d7ea"

    # without parsing changes
    # gem "rails", github: "rails/rails", branch: "main", ref: "e83cfa5466255d48cf03308dfe5d183eb8444d51"

    gem "rack", "~> 2"
  end

  require "action_controller/railtie"

  class TestApp < Rails::Application
    config.root = __dir__
    config.hosts << "example.org"
    config.secret_key_base = "secret_key_base"

    config.logger = Logger.new($stdout)
    Rails.logger  = config.logger

    routes.draw do
      get "/foo" => "test#index"
    end
  end

  class TestController < ActionController::Base
    include Rails.application.routes.url_helpers

    def index
      render(plain: params.to_s)
    end
  end

  require "minitest/autorun"
  require "rack/test"

  class BugTest < ActiveSupport::TestCase
    include Rack::Test::Methods

    QUERIES = [
      "cart[apple]=1&cart[banana]=2", # the only format that keeps working against any version rails/rack
      "[cart][apple]=1&[cart][banana]=2",
      "cart%5D%5Bapple%5D=1&%5Bcart%5D%5Bbanana%5D=2",
    ]

    def test_controller_returns_success
      expected = %({"cart"=>{"apple"=>"1", "banana"=>"2"}, "controller"=>"test", "action"=>"index"})
      QUERIES.each_with_index do |query, index|
        get("/foo?#{query}")
        assert_equal(expected, last_response.body, "Query with index #{index} failed. Query: #{query}")
      end
    end

    def test_action_dispatch_parse_query_parameters
      QUERIES.each_with_index do |query, index|
        env = {
          "QUERY_STRING" => query,
          "REQUEST_METHOD" => "GET",
          "rack.input" => StringIO.new,
          "CONTENT_LENGTH" => "0",
          "CONTENT_TYPE" => "application/x-www-form-urlencoded",
        }
        request = ActionDispatch::Request.new(env)
        params = request.query_parameters
        expected = { "cart" => { "apple" => "1", "banana" => "2" } }
        assert_equal(expected, params, "Query with index #{index} failed. Query: #{query}")
      end
    end

    private

    def app
      Rails.application
    end
  end
  ```

</details>

issue.title: Maintain Rack 2 parameter parsing behaviour
issue.body:
When running under Rack 3, we'll proceed with the new behaviour. That means we won't affect applications that already use Rack 3, but does also mean we can't help an application that is simultaneously bumping Rails and Rack together. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

However, with this commit, we at least ensure we maintain compatibility for applications that are currently still on Rack 2 -- and we can help with the transition using deprecation warnings... though there's admittedly a decent chance such warnings will only show up in production.

Fixes #53394
